metadata.case_name: Malegaon Powerloom Sadi Manufacturers Cooperative Association Ltd. Chairman v. State

facts.text: Appellant was the Chairman of the Malegaon Powerloom Sadi Manufacturers Cooperative Association Ltd. (Association), consisting of six powerloom weavers.

Appellant, as Chairman, applied for and obtained import licence dated January 2, 1956, for art silk yarn by the Association, subject to condition that goods would be utilised only for consumption as raw material in licence-holder's factory and no portion sold to any party.
Association could not arrange finances, so had goods imported through Warden Co., who financed the transaction.

Part of goods received was utilised per licence condition; rest sold by Warden Co. as result of correspondence ending with appellant's letter dated November 13, 1956, stating price of art silk yarn fallen, Association unable to take delivery of balance, requesting Warden Co. to dispose of balance goods without loss to Association but with net profit of at least 4%.
After disposal, Warden Co. paid Rs. 5,040/- to Association as profits.
Appellant and other members prosecuted under s.5 of Imports and Exports Control Act, 1947 for contravening Imports Control Order, 1955; acquitted by trial court.

State appealed against acquittal of appellant alone to Bombay High Court; appeal allowed on August 3, 1961, convicting appellant under s.5 of Act, sentencing to three months rigorous imprisonment and fine of Rs. 2,000/-.
Appeal by special leave to Supreme Court.

legal_issues.text: Whether Act intended only for prohibiting/controlling imports/exports at entry point, so condition on post-import disposal invalid under s.3 of Act.
Whether Order provides for condition prohibiting sale of imported goods.
Whether contravention of licence condition amounts to contravention of Act or Order, punishable under s.5 of Act.
Whether offence committed by Association (licensee), not its Chairman.
Whether Association guilty without possession of goods.

petitioner_arguments.text: Act per s.2/3 only for import/export at borders; post-import disposal condition invalid.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s.2, s.3 Imports and Exports Control Act, 1947; State of Bombay v. F.N. Balsara

petitioner_arguments.text: Order does not provide for no-sale condition.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Imports Control Order, 1955; East India Commercial Co. v. Collector of Customs

petitioner_arguments.text: Licence condition contravention not punishable under s.5 Act.

court_reasoning.text: Power under s.3 extends to post-import control for effective import control; policy considerations require control over utilisation.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Control not limited to entry; extends to disposal to prevent diversion.

court_reasoning.text: Cl.5(2) Order wide enough for no-sale condition; unlike prior orders.
Cl.5(4) requires compliance; contravention of condition = contravention of Order, punishable under s.5.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Prior cases inapplicable due to different order provisions.

court_reasoning.text: Association contravened as licensee; possession not necessary; Warden Co. agent.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Chairman abetted as he intentionally aided via letter.

court_reasoning.text: Actual possession unnecessary; Warden's possession = Association's.
High Court found mens rea; appellant intentionally aided/ abetted contravention.
Sentence not severe; deliberate misuse from beginning.

holdings.text: Cl.5 Order valid under s.3 Act; covers post-import disposal.
Licence contravention = Order contravention, punishable under s.5.

precedents_cited.case_name: State of Bombay v. F. N. Balsara
precedents_cited.relevance: Different context under Govt. of India Act entries; limited meaning of import there not applicable.

precedents_cited.case_name: Glass Chatons Importers Users Association v. Union of India
Daya v. Joint Chief Controller of Imports and Exports
East India Commercial Co. v. Collector of Customs
C. T. A. Pillai v. H. P. Lohia

statutes_cited.name: Imports and Exports (Control) Act, 1947
statutes_cited.relevance: Empowers prohibition/restriction/control of imports; penalty for contravention.

statutes_cited.name: Imports Control Order, 1955
statutes_cited.relevance: Conditions on licences including no disposal without permission; compliance mandatory.

outcome.summary: Appeal dismissed; High Court conviction and sentence under s.5 of Act upheld as all contentions rejected; appellant guilty of abetting Association's contravention of licence condition via intentional aid in sale of imported goods.

key_quotes.text: "the power conferred under s. 3 of the Act is not restricted merely to prohibiting or restricting imports at the point of entry but extends also to controlling the subsequent disposal of the goods imported."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on scope of s.3.

key_quotes.text: "The contravention of any condition of a licence thus amounts to the contravention of the provisions of sub-cl. (4) of cl. 5 of the Order and consequently to the contravention of the Order made under the Act."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Links licence breach to penal provision.

key_quotes.text: "the appellant, as Chairman, authorised Warden Co., to dispose of the goods... and therefore abetted the contravention."
key_quotes.speaker: court
